Name: CSR_Gauss-Seidel
Relation: { [i,j] -> [ip,jp] : i<ip && i=colidx(jp) && 0 <= i && i < m && 0 <= ip && ip < m && rowptr(i) <= j && j < rowptr(i+1) && rowptr(ip) <= jp && jp < rowptr(ip+1) }
Expected: { [i] -> [ip,jp] : i=colidx(jp) && colidx(jp) < ip && ip < m-1 && rowptr(i) < rowptr(i+1) && rowptr(ip) <= jp && jp < rowptr(ip+1) && colidx(jp) >= 0 && rowptr(i) >= 0 && rowptr(ip) >= 0 && rowptr(i+1) < nnz && rowptr(ip+1) < nnz}
Comment: Code: Following is the Gauss-Seidel code. Dependence analysis of
this code would identify 1 pair of read/write data accesses
(in S1) that may produce data dependences. This pair produces
two distinct conjunctions considering the ordering of accesses
(Flow and Anti dependence). Overall, there are 2 distinct
conjunctions for the complete dependence relation.
Comment: Source of data access in the co: a read in S1 (y[colidx[j]]);  a write in S1 (y[i]);

Name: CSR_Gauss-siedel
Relation: { [i,j] -> [ip,jp] : ip<i && i=colidx(jp) && 0 <= i && i < m && 0 <= ip && ip < m && rowptr(i) <= j && j < rowptr(i+1) && rowptr(ip) <= jp && jp < rowptr(ip+1) }
Expected: { [i] -> [ip,jp] : i=colidx(jp) && 0 <= ip && ip < colidx(jp) && rowptr(i) < rowptr(i+1) && rowptr(ip) <= jp && jp < rowptr(ip+1) && colidx(jp) < m-1 && rowptr(i) >= 0 && rowptr(ip) >= 0 && rowptr(i+1) < nnz && rowptr(ip+1) < nnz}
Comment: Source of data access in the co: a read in S1 (y[colidx[j]]);  a write in S1 (y[i]);
